# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Thinks There's No Better Way To Go Into The Weekend Than With Some Cravath Cash
## Woohoo! Congrats!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 4, 2022 at 4:16 PMMarch 4, 2022 at 3:34 PM
28
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/orrick-raise-2022/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Thinks%20There’s%20No%20Better%20Way%20To%20Go%20Into%20The%20Weekend%20Than%20With%20Some%20Cravath%20Cash)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/orrick-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/orrick-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What better way to end the week than with a big raise? That’s what management at many a firm thought today, because Biglaw is swimming in cold, hard cash.

The latest firm to increase associate salaries is Orrick, which is currently ranked at No. 35 on the Am Law 100, with $1,152,850,000 gross revenue in 2020. The firm is matching the now prevailing Cravath salary scale, which tops out at $415,000 for senior associates.

This is what the new salary scale looks like at Orrick:



This new salary scale is effective as of January 1, 2022, and associates will see the cash in their March 31 paychecks. Congratulations to everyone at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Orrick.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Milbank) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Milbank”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 10.19.16
## * The LSAT may be "destroy[ing] socioeconomic diversity" in law schools. Will a low score on the Logic Games section of the LSAT keep you from becoming employed as a lawyer? Probably not, but it may keep you from attending a top law school, unless you can afford an expensive LSAT tutor, and many prospective law students are priced out from the get-go. [[The Atlantic](http://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/10/the-lsat-is-rigged-against-the-poor/504530/)] * Darby Dickerson, dean of Texas Tech Law, is resigning to assume the deanship at John Marshall Law-Chicago, a school whose enrollment has faltered over the past several years. She was asked during a job interview why she would leave a ranked law school for an unranked one, and her response may surprise you. [[Crain's Chicago Business](http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20161017/NEWS04/161019841/new-dean-for-downsized-john-marshall-law-school)] * The first oral argument of the new SCOTUS term marked one of the first times that complete gender equality was reached at the high court. Five men -- all justices -- and five women -- three of them justices and two of them representing their clients -- were all present for Bravo-Fernandez, which is a relative rarity. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/for-a-rare-moment-at-the-supreme-court-the-genders-were-on-equal-footing/2016/10/17/6a56acbc-923d-11e6-a6a3-d50061aa9fae_story.html)] * "I feel that as a result of the experiences I had, I had a lot to offer." With the assistance of Dewey & LeBoeuf's former GC, Hinshaw & Culbertson is launching a crisis management and consulting practice. The firm is now in competition with businesses like Zeughauser Group, Altman Weil, and Hildebrandt Consulting. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/law-firm-launches-consulting-practice-for-other-law-firms/)] * A class-action suit has been filed over Samsung's recall of its fiery smartphone, alleging breach of warranty, breach of good faith, and common law fraud. You can expect the size of the proposed nationwide class of plaintiffs in this suit (or at least those in California, Pennsylvania, and Nevada) to explode faster than the Galaxy Note 7. [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/10/18/samsung-faces-class-action-over-galaxy-note-7-recalls/?ref=/blogs/law)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)

* The LSAT may be “destroy[ing] socioeconomic diversity” in law schools. Will a low score on the Logic Games section of the LSAT keep you from becoming employed as a lawyer? Probably not, but it may keep you from attending a top law school, unless you can afford an expensive LSAT tutor, and many prospective law students are priced out from the get-go. [[The Atlantic](http://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/10/the-lsat-is-rigged-against-the-poor/504530/)]

* Darby Dickerson, dean of Texas Tech Law, is resigning to assume the deanship at John Marshall Law-Chicago, a school whose enrollment has faltered over the past several years. She was asked during a job interview why she would leave a ranked law school for an unranked one, and her response may surprise you. [[Crain’s Chicago Business](http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20161017/NEWS04/161019841/new-dean-for-downsized-john-marshall-law-school)]


[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
* The first oral argument of the new SCOTUS term marked one of the first times that complete gender equality was reached at the high court. Five men — all justices — and five women — three of them justices and two of them representing their clients — were all present for Bravo-Fernandez, which is a relative rarity. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/for-a-rare-moment-at-the-supreme-court-the-genders-were-on-equal-footing/2016/10/17/6a56acbc-923d-11e6-a6a3-d50061aa9fae_story.html)]

* “I feel that as a result of the experiences I had, I had a lot to offer.” With the assistance of Dewey & LeBoeuf’s former GC, Hinshaw & Culbertson is launching a crisis management and consulting practice. The firm is now in competition with businesses like Zeughauser Group, Altman Weil, and Hildebrandt Consulting. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/law-firm-launches-consulting-practice-for-other-law-firms/)]

* A class-action suit has been filed over Samsung’s recall of its fiery smartphone, alleging breach of warranty, breach of good faith, and common law fraud. You can expect the size of the proposed nationwide class of plaintiffs in this suit (or at least those in California, Pennsylvania, and Nevada) to explode faster than the Galaxy Note 7. [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/10/18/samsung-faces-class-action-over-galaxy-note-7-recalls/?ref=/blogs/law)]

By KATIE ADAMS - MEDCITY NEWS

# Elite West Coast Firm Matches $205K Market Salaries
## Will any other law firms match this one's generosity towards summer associates?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 17, 2021 at 12:42 PMJune 17, 2021 at 12:56 PM
29
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-west-coast-firm-matches-205k-market-salaries/&text=Elite%20West%20Coast%20Firm%20Matches%20$205K%20Market%20Salaries)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-west-coast-firm-matches-205k-market-salaries/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-west-coast-firm-matches-205k-market-salaries/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Many associates on the West Coast seem to be waiting for Godot when it comes to their firms announcing the adoption of new $205K market salaries, but other firms have quickly gotten in gear and decided to pay associates what they owe them for their intense dedication.

One of those firms is Munger Tolles & Olson, a preeminent Am Law 200 firm that we’ve likened to the Wachtell of the West for attracting top talent. Today, perhaps in celebration of winning the Affordable Care Act case before the Supreme Court, the firm decided to match the new salary scale. If you’ve somehow forgotten, this is what it looks like at the firm:

- 2021: $202,500
- 2020: $205,000
- 2019: $215,000
- 2018: $240,000
- 2017: $275,000
- 2016: $305,000
- 2015: $330,000
- 2014: $350,000
- 2013+: $365,000
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
In even brighter news, the firm is making its match for summer associates retroactive to the beginning of the summer. That’s a pretty nice hike.

Congratulations to everyone at Munger Tolles on their raises — especially the law students, who will now be the highest paid of all summer associates on this pay scale. Will any other law firms match Munger Tolles & Olson’s generosity towards summer associates? We certainly hope so!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Munger Tolles & Olson.)

Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Some Associates In Some Markets Get Raises At This Biglaw Firm
## No, it's not New York associates getting the love.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 23, 2021 at 1:43 PMJune 23, 2021 at 1:36 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/dorsey-raises/&text=Some%20Associates%20In%20Some%20Markets%20Get%20Raises%20At%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/dorsey-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/dorsey-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw raises are all the rage rn, but that doesn’t mean everyone is feeling the love. Take Dorsey & Whitney. While the firm is giving *some* associates raises, they have not moved up to the Davis Polk scale making its way through the industry.

So what is going on at the firm?

The firm’s managing partner, Bill Stoeri, announced that fourth-year and more senior associates in a limited number of offices (Minneapolis, Salt Lake City, Seattle, and Denver) will be getting raises. Effective July 5th, mid to senior associates can expect between a $10,000 to $15,000 raise ([full memo available on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/dorsey-raises/2/)). And it’s true, those offices were not previously on the $190,000 scale, so it’s not like those markets are getting a boost above Dorsey’s New York or Palo Alto offices. But it *does* mean partners at the firm sat down, thought about associate compensation, and decided the only places they were lacking were Minneapolis, Salt Lake City, Seattle, and Denver.

Dorsey associates, we want to hear from you! What do you think about the firm’s salary decision? Will they come back and raise salaries in other markets? Are you pissed the firm isn’t making a bigger salary splash? Text us to sound off: 646-820-8477.

So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Milbank) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Struggling Biglaw Firm At Crossroads. Again.
## Bye-bye transactional work.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 22, 2020 at 3:15 PMDecember 18, 2020 at 10:15 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/struggling-biglaw-firm-at-crossroads-again/&text=Struggling%20Biglaw%20Firm%20At%20Crossroads.%20Again.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/struggling-biglaw-firm-at-crossroads-again/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/struggling-biglaw-firm-at-crossroads-again/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Things are changing in a big way over at Irell & Manella. According to an in-depth [report at Law.com](https://www.law.com/2020/05/18/irell-manella-is-at-a-crossroads-once-again/) looking at the future of the firm, Irell is pivoting to focus on its intellectual property litigation practice, with most of the rainmaking falling on partner Morgan Chu and eschewing their transactional practice.

It seems the firm’s back was against the proverbial wall. Since 2014, the firm has lost 48 percent of its attorneys, down to just 82 lawyers from 159. That change has coincided with plummeting gross revenue from $247.5 million in 2014 to just $151.6 million last year. So yeah, some sort of change is needed.

“The writing was on the wall,” as one former Irell partner put it, when Jonathan Kagan, a member of Irell’s executive committee and chair of its hiring committee, wrote in an internal memo in early February that the firm would now focus solely on high-end IP and commercial litigation, abandoning most of its transactional practices.

It wasn’t an entirely deliberate pivot, as interviews with former partners, legal consultants and Kagan himself indicate. These sources describe a firm that has been struggling for years to define itself and trying to rebuild after a devastating spinoff that has led some partners to explore potential merger opportunities.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The struggle to define what is next for the firm is real. Kagan notes:

“For years we’ve been trying to evaluate what the options are for us,” he says. “There is a difference between exploring options and making actual decisions.”

He adds, “We’ve been gradually moving in this direction, then people figured out what we were doing.”

This isn’t the first time in fairly recent memory that the firm has had to switch up its strategic vision. In 2015, the firm lost ~1/6th of its attorneys over a two-day period when the litigation boutique of Hueston Hennigan was born.

The spinoff put Irell at a crossroads of sorts, with three paths emerging: It could have grown its transactional and commodity litigation practices, merged with another firm or retrenched. At the time, [former Irell executive committee member David Siegel] hinted to The American Lawyer that there was disagreement among the firm’s partners about the right approach: “Some of us would prefer to focus now on growing but doing it in a careful way,” he said. “Most of us—but not all of us—have that mindset.”

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Since then, the firm’s strategy toward lateral partners is described by Law.com as “piecemeal” and that’s resulted in a partnership revolving door, with whatever attempts the firm made to build its transactional practice being thwarted. There’s been downward pressure on the firm’s revenue (though their profitability has remained stable at around 65 percent) and so, a change in direction and focus is needed.

Firm leaders remain optimistic about the new and improved focus, particularly in light of COVID-19:

The recent changes may leave the firm in a better position to weather the economic storm caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, sources say. As of early May, Irell had avoided cutting pay or staff like many larger, higher-grossing law firms have done. The pandemic has affected some of Irell’s cases—Kagan says one of his trials was postponed—but every attorney at the firm is busy, which might not have been the case had Irell kept its transactional practice, Kagan says.

“In light of the coronavirus and the dislocation of the economy, Irell might have the last laugh on this whole thing,” one former partner says.

Best of luck to the firm as they try to weather the latest changes.

# Whatever Does Not Kill You
## Notes to my (legal) self.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onOctober 2, 2020 at 5:03 PMOctober 2, 2020 at 2:38 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/whatever-does-not-kill-you/&text=Whatever%20Does%20Not%20Kill%20You)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/whatever-does-not-kill-you/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/whatever-does-not-kill-you/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Olga V. Mack is the CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407) and [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# Diversity In The Legal Profession Has Flatlined Since The Great Recession; Who Is To Blame?
## When it comes to diversity, it doesn't just get better; we must make a real and sustained effort.
By [Renwei Chung](https://abovethelaw.com/author/renweichung/)  
onJanuary 6, 2017 at 4:31 PMFebruary 9, 2023 at 1:36 AM
80
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/diversity-in-the-legal-profession-has-flatlined-since-the-great-recession-who-is-to-blame/&text=Diversity%20In%20The%20Legal%20Profession%20Has%20Flatlined%20Since%20The%20Great%20Recession;%20Who%20Is%20To%20Blame?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/diversity-in-the-legal-profession-has-flatlined-since-the-great-recession-who-is-to-blame/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/diversity-in-the-legal-profession-has-flatlined-since-the-great-recession-who-is-to-blame/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“Confused scholars can’t interpret our scrolls / Your sky has holes / We know the young is old / Nastadamus tells us how the story gets told.”
— [Nas](http://genius.com/2446807)

This month, the National Association for Law Placement (NALP) published its [NALP 2016 Report on Diversity](https://www.nalp.org/uploads/2016NALPReportonDiversityinUSLawFirms.pdf), based on data collected for the 2016-2017 NALP Directory of Legal Employers (NDLE), its annual compendium of legal employer profiles. The report revealed that “the overall percentage of women associates has decreased more often than not since 2009, and the percentage of Black/African-American associates has declined every year since 2009, except for the small increase in 2016.”

Many fates and fortunes were devastated during our country’s last recession. As for diversity and inclusion, it turns out that any positive trend for diversity in the legal profession would [continue to be marginal ](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/12/what-could-disrupt-diversity-in-law-the-economy-stupid/)at best. Whereas the stock market has gone on to recover since the last recession, diversity in the legal profession has basically [flatlined](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/without-significant-changes-diversity-in-the-legal-profession-will-remain-on-life-support/) since that time. Women and Black/African-American associates have actually witnessed a net-decrease in their representation in the legal profession since the Great Recession:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Minority women and Black/African-American men and women continue to be the least well represented in law firms, at every level, and law firms must double down to make more dramatic headway among these groups most of all.

And, while the relatively high levels of diversity among the summer associate classes is always encouraging, the fact that representation falls off so dramatically for associates, and then again for partners, underscores that retention and promotion remain the primary challenges that law firms face with respect to diversity.  — James Leipold, NALP Executive Director

These patterns look even bleaker at the top. Minority women represent 2.76% of partners, while minority men account for 5.29% of partners, according to the [NALP report](https://www.nalp.org/uploads/2016NALPReportonDiversityinUSLawFirms.pdf).

In 2009, Black/African-American lawyers represented 1.71% of law firm partners. Today, Black/African-American lawyers represent 1.81% of partners.

Currently, Asian-Americans and Hispanics make up 3.13% and 2.31% of partners, respectively. Both groups have increased by less than 1% since 2009.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Many of the [solutions and recommendations](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/how-attorneys-and-law-firms-can-raise-the-floor-for-diversity-equity-and-inclusion-in-2017/) to increase diversity in the workplace are rather simple ideas, but this does this not mean they will be easy to implement.

In their book [The Daily Stoic: 366 Meditations on Wisdom, Perseverance, and the Art of Living](http://amzn.to/2iMueFX) (affiliate link), Ryan Holiday and Stephen Hanselman point out that most of us have to do something several times in order to truly learn it. One of the hallmarks of martial arts, military training, and athletic feats of almost any kind are the hours and hours of monotonous practice required to learn how to escape from a chokehold, execute maneuvers, or shoot the perfect jumper. Simply knowing isn’t enough; it must be absorbed. It must become part of us or we risk losing it the second we experience stress or difficulty, according to Holiday and Hanselman.

If law firms treat diversity and inclusion programs only as one-offs or inconsistent initiatives, without truly ingraining them into their cultures and understanding what actually works, then it is likely the next recession will be [as devastating to diversity as the last recession](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/12/what-could-disrupt-diversity-in-law-the-economy-stupid/). We cannot afford another seven-year setback.

We have access to and have received the [data in our profession](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/09/92-of-biglaw-partners-are-white-is-this-problematic/). But as Charles Duhigg highlights in his book [Smarter Faster Better: The Secrets of Being Productive in Life and Business](http://amzn.to/2iMsUTe) (affiliate link), receiving information is not nearly enough. We must engage with the data instead of passively absorbing it. According to Duhigg, engaging with the data makes it “‘disfluent’ — harder to process at first, but stickier once it [is] really understood…. there’s a difference between finding an answer and understanding what it means.” Is the legal profession currently suffering from “information blindness” — the inability to take advantage of data as it becomes more plentiful?

Where the diversity statistics haven’t fallen since 2009, we have witnessed only incremental increases. So who is to blame for the diversity dilemma in the legal profession? The answer is simple: we all are. Law schools, law firms, and lawyers can all do more to [raise the floor](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/how-attorneys-and-law-firms-can-raise-the-floor-for-diversity-equity-and-inclusion-in-2017/).

###Sponsored

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Instead of just hoping matters will improve, while watching diversity continue to wither on the vine, we should engage with the data and understand what this means for our profession. We should no longer just trust that improvement will be made. We should become watchmen and watchwomen for diversity. If not us, who? Failing to verify best practices and procedures led us to the ramifications of the last recession. Hopefully we have learned our lesson.

For, as Benjamin Franklin once said, “without continual growth and progress, such words as improvement, achievement, and success have no meaning.”

[2016 Report on Diversity in U.S. Law Firms](https://www.nalp.org/uploads/2016NALPReportonDiversityinUSLawFirms.pdf) [NALP]
[Women and Minorities Make Slow Progress in Filling Ranks at Law Firms](http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/04/business/dealbook/law-firm-diversity-women-minorities.html?_r=0) [Dealbook / New York Times]

[Renwei Chung](https://www.linkedin.com/in/taichung/) is the DEI Columnist at [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/renweichung/). He currently serves as a Board Advisor for [The Diversity Movement (TDM)](https://thediversitymovement.com/dei-navigator/), whose integrated approach enables law firms to build and strengthen culture by tying real-world business outcomes to DEI initiatives via a scalable subscription-based employee experience platform. And he is excited to host TDM’s and Footnote 4’s new podcast Charge the Wave — focused on entrepreneurs, executives, and icons who are assiduously building companies, cultures, and communities.

# As Law Firms Start Layoffs, Alternative Legal Services Providers Grow Like Gangbusters
## Biglaw firms that haven't entered the ALSP market might want to get a move on.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 31, 2023 at 11:17 AMFebruary 1, 2023 at 12:00 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/as-law-firms-start-layoffs-alternative-legal-services-providers-grow-like-gangbusters/&text=As%20Law%20Firms%20Start%20Layoffs,%20Alternative%20Legal%20Services%20Providers%20Grow%20Like%20Gangbusters)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/as-law-firms-start-layoffs-alternative-legal-services-providers-grow-like-gangbusters/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/as-law-firms-start-layoffs-alternative-legal-services-providers-grow-like-gangbusters/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Most law firms aren’t in the process of laying off associates. But [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/cooley-layoffs-2022/) and [Goodwin](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/am-law-20-firm-begins-layoffs/) have been upfront about force reductions and other firms seem to be… [less upfront about it](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/when-biglaw-firms-set-90-day-performance-targets-stealth-layoffs-cant-be-far-behind/). While we have no reason to believe the layoff bug will spill over to the rest of the law firm landscape, even limited layoffs cast a pall over the industry.

But while law firms nervously eye the future, Alternative Legal Services Providers are lighting cigars with $100 bills.

The latest iteration of the [Alternative Legal Services Providers 2023 Report](https://www.thomsonreuters.com/en-us/posts/legal/alsp-report-2023/) compiled by the Thomson Reuters Institute in partnership with The Center on Ethics and the Legal Profession at Georgetown Law and the Saïd Business School at the University of Oxford reveals that ALSPs now make up $20 billion of the legal market. That represents a compounded annual growth rate of 20 percent from 2019-2021.



Of course, this pales in comparison to the $800+ billion total legal market, but it’s all in the growth. Demand for legal services remains stagnant and clients will only countenance fee hikes for so long. ALSPs have a greased runway to start soaking up business.

And while most of that business flows to independent ALSPs and the Big Four always loom in the background, the fastest growing segment of the ALSP world are the “law firm captives,” the internal ALSPs law firms have built to keep business in house.

Law firm captives, while the smallest part of the ALSP market, are also the fastest growing of the groups. Law firms create captives in multiple ways: with a tight integration (often via an acquisition or equity stake) with an independent ALSP; through an incubator or accelerator for technology-enabled service providers; or by starting a new company or line of business within the parent firm. Such entities now account for about $1 billion in revenues, showing 117% growth since our last report and a CAGR of 47%. Since 2015, the captive market has grown by 589%.

Even without keeping the business inside the firm, the report notes substantial increases among both large and midsize law firms citing ALSPs helping them retain clients.

It’s not all good news though. Corporate law departments already using ALSPs are divided on where they plan to go from here with 21 percent planning to increase ALSP spend, while 22 percent are either decreasing spend or are unsure. Still, that’s likely a net increase when all is said and done and the report also notes that law departments that don’t currently use ALSPs have increased interest in doing so.

There’s a lot in this report, but the primary takeaway is that if there were ever a battle between law firms and ALSPs for work, that’s over. The strategic challenge of the next decade is figuring out which industry players — law firms, in-house, accounting firms — best leverage ALSP concepts.

[Alternative Legal Services Providers 2023 Report](https://www.thomsonreuters.com/en-us/posts/legal/alsp-report-2023/) [Thomson Reuters Institute]

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# Elite Law Firms Recognized As Some Of The Best For Women & Diversity (2023)
## Which firms made the cut for this year’s ranking?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 1, 2023 at 1:44 PMJune 1, 2023 at 12:57 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/elite-law-firms-recognized-as-some-of-the-best-for-women-diversity-2023/&text=Elite%20Law%20Firms%20Recognized%20As%20Some%20Of%20The%20Best%20For%20Women%20&%20Diversity%20(2023))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/elite-law-firms-recognized-as-some-of-the-best-for-women-diversity-2023/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/elite-law-firms-recognized-as-some-of-the-best-for-women-diversity-2023/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Year in and year out, we watch law firm after law firm pay lip service to their commitment to diversity in the legal profession, with promises to put women attorneys on equal footing with their male counterparts, whether it be through hiring and retaining more women attorneys, promoting more women attorneys to equity partnership ranks, providing more leadership positions to women attorneys, or adopting more family-friendly policies to ensure that women attorneys are able to excel at their jobs while maintaining a stable work/life balance. Despite these continued assurances, and despite the fact that a number of firms have made great efforts to improve women’s stature in the law, there is still much more to be done — and we know which firms are working hard to do it.

Today, Seramount (formerly known as Working Mother Media) released its sixteenth annual list of the Best Law Firms for Women & Diversity. These law firms are considered pioneers in the field when it comes to attracting, retaining, and promoting women lawyers. These law firms not only stand out as being family-friendly workplaces, but they also ensure that women shine in their equity partnership ranks.

Which firms made the cut for this year’s ranking?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
To earn themselves a spot on the Best Law Firms list, self-selected applicant firms must complete an extensive application (more than 300 questions long) with topics ranging from attorney representation, schedule flexibility, paid time off and parental leaves, and development and retention of women and people of color. Questions also included family-friendly benefits, and mentoring and sponsorship participation. Seramount then selected the best firms based on data provided by those firms from the year 2022. “I’m proud to expand our Best Law Firms for Women to include diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts,” said Subha V. Barry, president of Seramount. “From increasing representation of historically excluded talent to expanding upon their family-friendly benefits, our Best Law Firms are putting in the work necessary to build firm cultures where employees can thrive.”

So what do we know about the recognized firms? Forty-two percent of lawyers at these firms are women, 23 percent of lawyers at these firms are women of color, and 41 percent of women lawyers hired at these firms are women of color. Twenty-seven percent of equity partners are women, while the percentage of women promoted to equity partner is 39 percent. The firms average 17 weeks of paid gender-neutral parental leave and 90 percent of the firms subsidize childcare.

For the first time, Seramount has revealed the top five firms. Here they are (in alphabetical order):

- Arnold & Porter
- Littler
- Morrison Foerster
- Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe LLP
- Perkins Coie

# Law Firms Should Consider Hosting Holiday Parties This Year
## Interacting with other lawyers at such industry events is good for networking, business development, and a variety of other purposes.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onNovember 3, 2021 at 6:18 PMNovember 3, 2021 at 3:00 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/law-firms-should-consider-hosting-holiday-parties-this-year/&text=Law%20Firms%20Should%20Consider%20Hosting%20Holiday%20Parties%20This%20Year)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/law-firms-should-consider-hosting-holiday-parties-this-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/law-firms-should-consider-hosting-holiday-parties-this-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The annual holiday party is a fixture of many law firms across the United States. Such parties allow associates, partners, and staff to unwind, meet up in a more relaxed environment, and celebrate the holiday season. Very few law firms hosted holiday parties last year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but as vaccination rates increase, and more law firms return to the office, many shops should consider hosting holiday parties this year.

Before starting my own practice several years ago, I worked at a handful of big and smaller law firms. Each law firm at which I worked hosted a holiday party. The biggest firm I worked at hosted a huge shindig as a swanky country club, and the smallest firm I worked at hosted a holiday party at a nearby bar. Although some people many not like the social tension that may be present at holiday parties, I always enjoyed going to these events.

Holiday parties are a great way to build rapport among people who work in an office. Individuals may interact with people at the office more than they interact with some members of their family. Yet, people usually only see their coworkers in a professional environment, wearing the same professional clothes, and talking about the same work-related matters. A holiday party is perhaps the one time in a year when individuals who work with each other can interact on a deeper level and forge bonds that can transcend just the coworker connection.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Indeed, the holiday parties I attended were some of the only times I got to see the partners unwind and view them more as colleagues than bosses. In addition, holiday parties were usually the only time I interacted with family members of people with whom I worked, which was always a great experience. Holiday parties were a fixture of all kinds of law firms for as long as I worked in the profession, likely due to all of the benefits these events can have at a firm.

Last year, practically no law firms hosted holiday parties, and this was the right move. During the holiday season, COVID-19 cases were on the rise, and it was one of the bleakest parts of the pandemic. The cold temperatures seemingly drove people indoors which has a negative impact on the amount of people who were impacted by COVID-19. In addition, although the COVID-19 vaccines began getting rolled out during last year’s holiday season, no one outside of a select group of people could obtain the vaccine. Almost all of the holiday events I heard of got cancelled in light of these conditions, and law firms were wise not to schedule holiday parties.

However, we can be cautiously optimistic that conditions this holiday season may permit law firms to hold holiday parties in some form. Vaccination rates are on the rise, and many law firms are requiring that attorneys get vaccinated in order to come to the office. In addition, COVID-19 case counts are going down (although it remains to be seen if this rate will continue into the holiday season). Based on these conditions, many law firms are requiring associates to return to offices, which has started the long path that lawyers and law firms must tread before things return to as close to the prepandemic normal as possible. Hosting holiday parties can be one way that law firms continue their trend of bringing people back together and normalizing operations in light of recent developments in the fight against COVID-19.

Legal organizations should also consider hosting the same holiday parties they once held, albeit perhaps in a modified format. During the holiday season, I loved attending a variety of industry holiday parties so that I could interact with lawyers who worked outside of my office. Without naming names, there was one court reporting service that used to host an epic holiday party, and people used to travel from hundreds of miles away in some situations to attend this annual event. In addition, Above the Law itself used to host one of the best holiday parties around, and it is a shame that this tradition has been interrupted due to COVID-19. Interacting with other lawyers at such industry events is good for networking, business development, and a variety of other purposes, and legal industry organizations should also consider hosting holiday parties this year.

Of course, measures should be taken to protect against COVID-19 at any holiday party. I am not an epidemiologist, but parties should be kept to a limited number of guests, and guest should likely have to prove that they are vaccinated or had a recent COVID-19 test before they attend such an event. At the very least, law firms should start thinking well in advance of the holiday season whether or not they should host holiday parties this year like they did before the COVID-19 pandemic.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothmanlawyer.com](mailto:jordan@rothmanlawyer.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# What's It Going To Take To Get This Biglaw Megamerger Across The Finish Line?
## All of the partners need to be on board, and that could be difficult.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 30, 2023 at 2:48 PMMay 30, 2023 at 2:23 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/whats-it-going-to-take-to-get-this-biglaw-megamerger-across-the-finish-line/&text=What’s%20It%20Going%20To%20Take%20To%20Get%20This%20Biglaw%20Megamerger%20Across%20The%20Finish%20Line?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/whats-it-going-to-take-to-get-this-biglaw-megamerger-across-the-finish-line/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/whats-it-going-to-take-to-get-this-biglaw-megamerger-across-the-finish-line/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

There is typically a lot of wood to chop to get to the finish of a transformative law firm combination. They will need to develop a business case that captures the hearts and minds of the equity partners.

There is also often a multidimensional chess to play because as much as a firm hopes its partners act in their firm’s best interests, unsurprisingly, there are some partners who start to think, ‘If our firm is not going to be the firm it has always been, maybe I should look at this like being a free agent’ and compare the new firm with others on the open market. Some firms have a culture where that happens a lot; others are more committed to the firm’s best interests.

— [Kent Zimmermann](https://www.consultzg.com/people/kent-zimmermann/), a legal industry consultant at the Zeughauser Group who has handled many law firm mergers, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/05/25/what-next-for-ao-and-shearman-firms-look-to-partnership-vote-first/) on the proposed merger between Allen & Overy and Shearman & Sterling. Zimmerman went on to note that “[c]omplacency during a combination in one firm can be a deal breaker,” adding that in prior mergers, he’s seen a lot of “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” from certain practice areas.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics
[A&O Shearman](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ao-shearman/), [Allen & Overy](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/allen-overy/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Law Firm Merger Mania](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/law-firm-merger-mania/), [Law Firm Mergers](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/law-firm-mergers/), [Partner Issues](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/partner-issues/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/), [Shearman & Sterling](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/shearman-sterling-llp/)

# Am Law 100 Firm Names Younger Partner As Chair Elect To Lead Alongside Non-Lawyer CEO
## The firm's new leader is about 20 years junior to the typical Biglaw chair -- and that's big news.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 31, 2024 at 1:43 PMJanuary 31, 2024 at 1:22 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/am-law-100-firm-names-younger-partner-as-chair-elect-to-lead-alongside-non-lawyer-ceo/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Names%20Younger%20Partner%20As%20Chair%20Elect%20To%20Lead%20Alongside%20Non-Lawyer%20CEO)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/am-law-100-firm-names-younger-partner-as-chair-elect-to-lead-alongside-non-lawyer-ceo/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/am-law-100-firm-names-younger-partner-as-chair-elect-to-lead-alongside-non-lawyer-ceo/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A slew of Biglaw firms are ushering in new leaders this year, but the latest firm to elect a new chair has done things a bit differently. What could be so unique about this new law firm leader, you may ask?

His age.

Husch Blackwell — a firm that brought in $555,836,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 81 in the most recent Am Law 100 — has named [Joe Glynias](https://www.huschblackwell.com/professionals/joe-glynias) as its chair elect. The St. Louis-based labor and employment lawyer has all the credentials your typical Biglaw leader comes equipped with, but there’s one thing that makes him stand out among his peers.

Glynias, a Husch Blackwell lifer who joined the firm about 21 years ago, is just 46 years old. Compared to other Biglaw chairs and managing partners, that makes him quite young. [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/husch-blackwell-names-glynias-46-firm-chair-bucking-age-trend) has more:

The incoming chair is significantly younger than the average Big Law leader. The average age of top leaders who departed top roles at the largest firms last year and this year was 66, The American Lawyer [reported](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/11/10/law-firm-leaders-may-be-tiring-of-the-job-but-thats-not-why-theyve-been-leaving/#:~:text=Chelsey%20Fredlund%2FALM-,The%20average%20tenure%20of%20top%20leaders%20departing%20in%202023-24,than%20the%202006-22%20group.) in November.

Glynias plans to maintain his active labor and employment practice after he takes over the firm’s leadership on April 1, alongside [Jamie Lawless](https://www.huschblackwell.com/professionals/jamie-lawless), who is set to become the firm’s CEO on February 1. Lawless is not a lawyer, and she’ll soon become the only business professional to lead an Am Law 100 firm.

Glynias offered the following in a statement about his upcoming leadership transition at the firm:

“I am extremely excited about Jamie serving as our next Chief Executive and helping her chart our course forward. Our firm defines itself in many uncommon ways, including that a successful law firm does not have to be run by a lawyer—particularly when a non-lawyer business professional of Jamie’s caliber has shown herself to be such an inspiring and competent leader.”

“I believe my role, and that of the Executive Board, is to support her and create an environment where she can best succeed, and I can’t wait to see what we can all do together. Our firm is beyond fortunate to be working from a position of strength and success based on the extraordinary work and dedication shown by Catherine Hanaway during her time as our Chair, for which we are all extremely grateful.”

Congratulations to Joe Glynias on his ascent to leadership at Husch Blackwell, and congratulations to the firm on forging this new pathway to success with Jamie Lawless.

[Husch Blackwell Names Glynias, 46, Firm Chair, Bucking Age Trend](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/husch-blackwell-names-glynias-46-firm-chair-bucking-age-trend) [Bloomberg Law]

# Nashville Is Biglaw's New Hot Spot
## Forget Miami. It's all about Music City now, y'all.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 12, 2023 at 3:44 PMJanuary 13, 2023 at 1:22 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/nashville-is-biglaws-new-hot-spot/&text=Nashville%20Is%20Biglaw’s%20New%20Hot%20Spot)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/nashville-is-biglaws-new-hot-spot/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/nashville-is-biglaws-new-hot-spot/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Nashville, in the health care industry world, is pretty much the epicenter of for-profit health care, where investors come to own health care. I don’t really see that changing, in terms of health care being of great interest to investors.

— [John Tishler](https://www.ebglaw.com/people/john-c-tishler/), a partner at Epstein Becker & Green, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/01/11/major-combinations-in-nashville-and-carolinas-signal-southeasts-emergence-as-merger-hotspot/), on this year’s strong merger activity within the Southeast, and the fact that firms are “hungry for growth” opportunities in Nashville’s specialized (and profitable) health care market. Tishler left health care firm Waller Lansden in November, and that firm recently [announced a merger](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/top-biglaw-firm-starts-new-year-off-on-right-foot-with-merger-announcement/) with Holland & Knight.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# How Attorneys Can Protect The Right To Vote
## PLI's half-day program will include an in-depth look at some of today’s biggest issues in voting.
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onMay 11, 2022 at 1:43 PMMay 11, 2022 at 1:11 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/how-attorneys-can-protect-the-right-to-vote/&text=How%20Attorneys%20Can%20Protect%20The%20Right%20To%20Vote)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/how-attorneys-can-protect-the-right-to-vote/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/how-attorneys-can-protect-the-right-to-vote/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With the midterm elections on the horizon and the Supreme Court weighing in on various voting-related cases, now is the perfect time to familiarize yourself  with the current election law landscape in the United States. 

If you’re interested in learning more — including the role attorneys can play in protecting voting rights — PLI has an upcoming program for you. 

The half-day program, [Voter Rights 2022](https://www.pli.edu/programs/voter-rights?t=live?tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), will give you an overview of voting laws in America, including constitutional and statutory standards, as well as recent developments in the law. 

The expert presenters will also take an in-depth look at some of today’s biggest issues in voting, including: 

- The history of voting rights in America
- Present day challenges to voting rights, including voter registration and voting access issues
- Redistricting and its impact on voting rights
- What attorneys can do to address challenges and protect voting rights 
[Register today](https://www.pli.edu/programs/voter-rights?t=live?tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2) to take part in this essential program.

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Government](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/government/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [On Course](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/on-course/), [On Course Practice](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/on-course-practice/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/)

# A&O Shearman Merger Approved, Poised To Become Third-Largest Firm In The World
## Make way for the next Biglaw behemoth. Congratulations!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 13, 2023 at 12:43 PMOctober 13, 2023 at 11:57 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/ao-shearman-merger-approved-poised-to-become-third-largest-firm-in-the-world/&text=A&O%20Shearman%20Merger%20Approved,%20Poised%20To%20Become%20Third-Largest%20Firm%20In%20The%20World)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/ao-shearman-merger-approved-poised-to-become-third-largest-firm-in-the-world/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/ao-shearman-merger-approved-poised-to-become-third-largest-firm-in-the-world/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s officially time to say hello to A&O Shearman, the newest Biglaw behemoth. After two weeks of voting, Allen & Overy and Shearman & Sterling jointly announced earlier this morning that their partnerships had officially approved the firms’ proposed merger. Combined, the firm will have nearly 4,000 lawyers with approximately 800 partners, spread across 48 offices. A&O Shearman’s revenue will total roughly $3.5 billion. As noted by the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/13/ao-shearman-has-lift-off-partners-give-green-light/), A&O Shearman is now set to become the third-largest law firm in the world.

According to a firm spokesperson, more than 99% of the votes cast at each firm were in favor of the merger. The firms published a [joint press release](https://www.shearman.com/en/news-and-events/news/2023/10/a-and-o-shearman-merger-approved) with comments from their respective leaders:

Wim Dejonghe, Senior Partner at Allen & Overy, said: “This is a historic moment for both firms and our profession. We are delighted that our partners have voted so resoundingly in favor of this merger, which is a transformational step for the legal industry. We have long admired Shearman & Sterling for its outstanding reputation, talent, and client base, and we are confident that together we will create a truly exceptional global firm that will serve our clients’ needs in an increasingly complex and dynamic world.”

Adam Hakki, Senior Partner at Shearman & Sterling, said: “Our partners have recognized and welcomed this unparalleled opportunity to combine our individual market leadership and brands to serve clients as an integrated global law firm, preeminent in all our markets. A&O Shearman will be a firm unlike any other in the world, built to achieve exceptional outcomes for our clients through an intentional focus on quality, excellence, and collaboration. We are creating a new industry leader, with truly global capabilities, and we are excited for what is to come.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Now that the merger has been approved, A&O Shearman is expected to be effective sometime this spring, likely in May 2024. Congratulations!

# The New Compensation Scale Is Spreading On The West Coast
## This move really amps up the pressure on other West Coast firms, which so far have been slow to act.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 9, 2016 at 5:51 PMFebruary 13, 2017 at 3:07 PM
36
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/money_on_the_west_coast/&text=The%20New%20Compensation%20Scale%20Is%20Spreading%20On%20The%20West%20Coast)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/money_on_the_west_coast/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/money_on_the_west_coast/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Looks like Biglaw firms don’t want to be left in the dust by their peer firms moving to the new [MoneyLaw scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/what-firms-miss-the-moneylaw-cut/). West Coast giant [O’Melveny & Myers](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/omelveny-myers/) is getting on board and giving raises to their associates.

The firm has yet to release an official memo or email, instead preferring to leave the information on voicemail — how very ’90s — but we’ve heard from a bevy of tipsters (we <3 you) that the raises are for all U.S. offices, are effective July 1, and fully match the scale set out by Cravath earlier this week.

A tipster does note the compensation grid only goes up to the class of 2008:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
No 2007 pay scale, which is annoying, and a departure from past practice.

UPDATE 7:16pm: We’ve received a little more detail about how those above the class of 2008 will be compensated:

To be fair the firm stated that the higher level counsel (2007 and senior, I think) would be individually determined. At least seems to leave open the possibility of being paid market, but wonder if/when that will be determined for the present year raise.

Still, a welcomed payday for associates. This move really [amps up the pressure](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/what-firms-miss-the-moneylaw-cut/) on other West Coast firms, which thus far have been slow to act.

# Supreme Court Frontrunner's Former Clerk Takes Devotion To New Heights
## Biglaw associate takes the battle to be the next Supreme Court justice to the pages of Wikipedia.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 8, 2022 at 10:43 AMFebruary 9, 2022 at 1:36 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/supreme-court-frontrunners-former-clerk-takes-devotion-to-new-heights/&text=Supreme%20Court%20Frontrunner’s%20Former%20Clerk%20Takes%20Devotion%20To%20New%20Heights)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/supreme-court-frontrunners-former-clerk-takes-devotion-to-new-heights/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/supreme-court-frontrunners-former-clerk-takes-devotion-to-new-heights/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The relationship between a judge and clerk is often described as a unique one that can inspire devotion and long lasting bonds. A meaningful clerkship relationship can change the course of a young lawyer’s career, opening up opportunities and experiences that would otherwise would be closed. And if “your” judge becomes a Supreme Court justice, an already prestigious resume line takes an even bigger shot in the arm.

So, it’s not surprising that former clerks of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson want her to get the nod to the Court from Joe Biden. She’s reportedly the frontrunner ([and who Above the Law readers believe will get the nomination](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/who-do-you-think-will-replace-stephen-breyer-on-the-supreme-court/)) to be the replacement for Stephen Breyer on the Supreme Court — and she’s a former Breyer clerk to boot. But according to a [report from Politico](https://www.politico.com/news/2022/02/04/former-clerk-rewrites-supreme-court-wikipedia-bios-00005914), one former clerk’s support of Brown Jackson has turned to an active online campaign.

According to Politico’s reporting, Matteo Godi, a former Brown Jackson clerk and current [Paul Weiss associate](https://www.paulweiss.com/professionals/associates/matteo-godi), under the username “H2rty” has “as a matter of course” edited his former [boss’s Wikipedia page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ketanji_Brown_Jackson) for a number of years. (Godi was identified as H2rty by an anonymous group of former Brown Jackson clerks.) But now that’s she’s on the shortlist of SCOTUS nominees, he’s reportedly taken to not only editing Brown Jackson’s page, but the pages of other contenders to make Brown Jackson seem like a more compelling selection. H2rty’s Wiki edits include Brown Jackson’s (natch) as well as J. Michelle Childs and Leondra Kruger, Wilhelmina Wright, Tiffany Cunningham, Arianna J. Freeman, and Holly Thomas. Which is basically every serious contender for the seat.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Some of the changes to Brown Jackson’s page seem to be aimed at shining her record:

The most recent changes to Jackson’s page appear to be an attempt at swaying left-leaning opinion in her favor. On Jan. 30 and Feb. 1, user H2rty made significant changes to the body of Jackson’s page, cutting a reference to Jackson’s position on an advisory board of “a Baptist school.” Descriptions of two of Jackson’s rulings against the Trump administration, both of which were reversed by the D.C. Circuit, were erased and replaced with a defense: “Ahead of her confirmation hearing, ‘Bloomberg Law’ reported that conservative activists were pointing to certain decisions by Jackson that had been reversed on appeal as a ‘potential blemish on her record,’ in order ‘to tarnish her so she won’t get picked for the Supreme Court.’”

The portion detailing Jackson’s most famous ruling, a decision to require former White House counsel Don McGahn to obey a congressional subpoena, was also tweaked. The New York Times noted Jackson’s “slow pace” helped then-President Donald Trump “run out the clock on the congressional oversight effort” before the 2020 election; Jackson’s updated Wikipedia page seems to shift the blame for the ruling’s timing from Jackson to the D.C. Circuit court.

Which has a decidedly different tenor than the recent edits to other shortlisters’ pages:

Edits to Childs’ and Kruger’s pages by the user took a decidedly different tone, emphasizing characteristics of the potential nominees that call into question their liberal bona-fides. A passage on Childs’ tenure at South Carolina-based law firm Nexsen Pruet notes her “reputation for being an expert in employment and labor law.” User H2rty added that Childs worked on behalf of “employers dealing with allegations of race based and gender based discrimination, employee efforts to unionize, and other alleged civil rights violations.”

Kruger’s page notes she is “sometimes considered one of the swing votes” on the California Supreme Court. H2rty added that she “is seen as a moderate on the seven-member court — moderately liberal on civil cases, more conservative on criminal matters.”

Of course, because it is a wiki, a Wikimedia spokesperson said this about the recent edits, “We do not write, edit, proofread, or determine what content is included on Wikipedia or how that content is maintained.” While Godi has remained silent about the attention his internet hobby has garnered.

# Get Your Vaccine And Get It Now: Biglaw Firms Want To Open Their Offices
## The flexibility ends when employee health is at stake.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 4, 2021 at 3:15 PMAugust 4, 2021 at 2:24 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/get-your-vaccine-and-get-it-now-biglaw-firms-want-to-open-their-offices/&text=Get%20Your%20Vaccine%20And%20Get%20It%20Now:%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Want%20To%20Open%20Their%20Offices)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/get-your-vaccine-and-get-it-now-biglaw-firms-want-to-open-their-offices/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/get-your-vaccine-and-get-it-now-biglaw-firms-want-to-open-their-offices/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Firms are becoming more firm about what they want people to do, particularly requiring vaccinations. There was a period where people were much more comfortable and willing to be flexible, but what I’m seeing at firms, and just generally, is people’s patience is wearing a little thin about this because they don’t want to continue in this way indefinitely.

— Jeffrey Lowe, practice leader of the law firm practice group at Major, Lindsey & Africa, commenting on the firms that have [recently mandated vaccinations for all employees in light of the rise of the Delta variant](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/08/04/peoples-patience-is-wearing-a-little-thin-whats-spurring-vaccine-mandates-at-some-big-law-firms/). Law firms would like to reopen their offices and don’t want a wrench to be thrown into those plans due to COVID outbreaks. In order to protect their employees and prevent illness, required vaccinations for all is a perfect way to accomplish both goals.

# Is Skadden Arps Handing Out Retention Bonuses To Only *Some* Associates?
## If you can stay at the firm for another year, you could get a bunch of extra money.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 12, 2021 at 1:13 PMAugust 13, 2021 at 10:13 AM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/is-skadden-arps-handing-out-retention-bonuses-to-only-some-associates/&text=Is%20Skadden%20Arps%20Handing%20Out%20Retention%20Bonuses%20To%20Only%20*Some*%20Associates?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/is-skadden-arps-handing-out-retention-bonuses-to-only-some-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/is-skadden-arps-handing-out-retention-bonuses-to-only-some-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We know the Biglaw lateral market is super hot right now. So if associates are unhappy for even the slightest reason, they’re probably looking at other opportunities. And firms *know* that, hence they’re throwing money at associates (in the form of special bonuses and raises). But is that enough to keep valuable associates at the firm?

Well, it looks like Skadden is giving associates even more money to keep them at the firm — but there’s a catch. According to numerous tipsters, associates are getting retention bonuses — on top of all the money previously publicized — but there’s a catch. It only goes to associates in certain, highly sought after practice groups, namely M&A and capital markets in the New York office. According to insiders, the firm is making the payments on the DL so as not to rock the boat with practice groups left out of the largesse. That means there is no memo — bonuses have been communicated individually by phone.

We are hearing reports of *lots* of six-figure bonuses going out to junior (though not first-year) through senior associates, but truly the midlevels appear to be the target of the move. And finally the real kicker: associates have to be employed at the firm as of June 30, 2022 to get the bonus.

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

So… Skaddenites, we have some questions for you: Are other practice groups getting these retention bonuses? Are first-year associates truly left out in the cold? Are other offices besides New York getting in on the action?

The other query is: how widespread is this in the industry? Can we expect other elite firms to do the same — or are they already doing so?

You know the drill — hit us up! Please don’t hesitate to let us know whatever details you have on retention bonuses. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. # Above The Law’s 2018 Lawyer Of The Year Contest: The Winner!
## With competitors like the special counsel and a sitting Supreme Court justice, you may be surprised by this year's winner.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 22, 2019 at 11:31 AMJanuary 22, 2019 at 10:57 AM
39
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/above-the-laws-2018-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/&text=Above%20The%20Law’s%202018%20Lawyer%20Of%20The%20Year%20Contest:%20The%20Winner!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/above-the-laws-2018-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/above-the-laws-2018-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The competition for 2018 Lawyer of the Year honors was not a close competition, not even one little bit. The top three candidates — Michael Avenatti, Robert Mueller, and Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg — each had votes in the hundreds, but the new titleholder secured almost 300 more votes than the second-place finisher.

Before we announce which one of the three prevailed, let’s review Above the Law’s past Lawyers of the Year:

- 2007: [Loyola 2L](https://abovethelaw.com/2008/01/featured-survey-results-and-the-winners-are------/)
- 2008: [President Barack Obama](https://abovethelaw.com/2008/12/associate-life-survey-lawyer-of-the-year/)
- 2009: [Justice Sonia Sotomayor](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/01/atls-lawyer-of-the-year-the-winner/)
- 2010: [Law School Transparency’s Kyle McEntee and Patrick Lynch](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/01/atls-lawyer-of-the-year-2010-the-winner/)
- 2011: [Professor Paul Campos](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/01/atls-2011-lawyer-of-the-year-the-winner/)
- 2012: [Chief Justice John Roberts](https://abovethelaw.com/2013/01/above-the-laws-2012-lawyer-of-the-year-competition-the-winner/)
- 2013: [Roberta Kaplan](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/01/above-the-laws-2013-lawyer-of-the-year-competition-the-winner/)
- 2014: [Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/01/above-the-laws-2014-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/)
- 2015: [Bryan “Law Hawk” Wilson](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/above-the-laws-2015-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/)
- 2016: [Don McGahn](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/above-the-laws-2016-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/)
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
You’ll see they come from basically two camps: “famous famous,” like President Obama and the three Supreme Court justices, and “ATL famous,” like the various critics of the law school industrial complex. Which camp won out this year?


Michael Avenatti (Photo by Jennifer S. Altman/For The Washington Post via Getty Images)

Famous famous — or some would even say infamous. Michael Avenatti, the lawyer for former adult film actress Stormy Daniels, who would go on to start a chain of events that would eventually send another lawyer to jail (Michael Cohen, who finished this competition in second-to-last place) and add fuel to the fire in the FBI investigation of a sitting president, stole this competition with 44 percent of the entire vote. Like no other attorney, he was able to dominate the news throughout the course of the year and developed such a fan club that he even thought of (and then thought better of) running for president.

Congratulations to all our Lawyer of the Year finalists, and very special congratulations to our 2018 Lawyer of the Year, Michael Avenatti. Thanks to his incredibly zealous client representation and his habit of inserting himself into every pop culture legal event, America will never be the same. Well done!
