# Midwestern Biglaw Firm Uses Merger To Get Into The New York Market
## Smaller firms unite to become one big team.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 23, 2021 at 3:44 PM
27
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/midwestern-biglaw-firm-uses-merger-to-get-into-the-new-york-market/&text=Midwestern%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Uses%20Merger%20To%20Get%20Into%20The%20New%20York%20Market)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/midwestern-biglaw-firm-uses-merger-to-get-into-the-new-york-market/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/midwestern-biglaw-firm-uses-merger-to-get-into-the-new-york-market/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We think the value proposition that we offer to our associates includes a lot of things you can’t find at the bigger firms. A place where you can grow your practices and become a partner—at larger firms that can be very difficult to achieve sometimes. —[Roman Wuller](https://www.thompsoncoburn.com/people/roman-wuller)

As a small firm, we’ve always had to try hard to catch up to the big boys, and we’ve done our best. I think what resonated with our associates, when we announced no layoffs, no cuts—to the extent there was a downturn in the market, we would all weather that storm together. That garnered a lot of loyalty. —[Mark Indelicato](http://mobile.hahnhessen.com/attorneys/indelicato-mark)

— [Roman Wuller](https://www.thompsoncoburn.com/people/roman-wuller), chair of Thompson Coburn, and [Mark Indelicato](http://mobile.hahnhessen.com/attorneys/indelicato-mark), managing partner of financial boutique Hahn & Hessen, commenting on one of the [reasons they knew a merger between their two firms](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2021/06/23/new-york-firm-and-thompson-coburn-to-merge-eyeing-benefits-of-scale/) would work: because of the values their firms share. The combined firm will have more than 400 lawyers across seven offices, and their combined revenue would have been about $240 million in 2020. Now the Biglaw firm, ranked at No. 149 in the most recent Am Law 100, will have much greater access to the New York market.

# Why 'Humanizing' Technology Will Empower Legal Teams
## Empathy, communication, and continuous improvement are keys to successful technology use.
By ELIZABETH LUGONES  
onFebruary 15, 2024 at 2:14 PMFebruary 15, 2024 at 1:14 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/why-humanizing-technology-will-empower-legal-teams/&text=Why%20‘Humanizing’%20Technology%20Will%20Empower%20Legal%20Teams)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/why-humanizing-technology-will-empower-legal-teams/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/why-humanizing-technology-will-empower-legal-teams/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Successful legal tech selection, implementation, and adoption require legal departments and the organizations in which they sit to prioritize the needs of the people interacting with the technology and the processes it will enable.

One of the desired outcomes of successfully leveraging technology is that people are enabled to work at their optimal level of proficiency and capabilities. We call this “humanizing technology.”

This practice focuses on the user experience and the necessity of making legal tools, processes, and their output accessible. 

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Following are areas where legal departments should focus their efforts:

Empathy and User-Centered Design

Involve end-users, such as legal professionals and clients, in the selection, design implementation, and testing phases to ensure that the technology meets their needs and is easy to use.

This is where the corporate buzzwords “process optimization” come into play.

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Infuse empathy into the design process. Understand the challenges and pain points of stakeholders (legal and business) to design processes and technology solutions that address their needs. Integrate legal technology seamlessly into existing workflows. Avoid disrupting established processes and ensure that the technology enhances efficiency rather than creating additional burdens.

User-centric design requires evaluating and understanding how the active participants in the process interact in the environment and what the company’s culture/industry is. By doing this, organizations ensure the key participants are taken into account in selection and implementation.  

Clear Communication and Storytelling

Clear and transparent communication is important to build team support and executive buy-in.

User-centered design includes communication with individuals impacted by or benefiting from change.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Take this opportunity not only to understand their needs and collect data points but also to tell the story and pressure test the future state vision for how technology will benefit them and ease their points of friction. 

Lawyers are skilled problem solvers. When they are presented with an issue, they interpret law and precedent and come back with legal analysis to provide guidance to their client. 

In the case of technology implementation, this approach leads to failure and frustration. 

Technology design should be a collaborative effort to uncover what will achieve the desired results for the majority of the parties involved. It involved bridging the gap of understanding by being fully transparent, compromising, influencing, and solving together.

Unlike in Field of Dreams, if you build it, he will NOT come. You cannot buy and implement technology, plug it in, and expect everyone to use it.

You must inspire and incentivize people every step of the way to understand the value technology will bring once it is in place. 

Feedback and Continuous Improvement

During the design phase, include a governance model to manage the technology owners and incorporate feedback mechanisms to gather input from users.

Actively seek feedback and use it to make continuous improvements, demonstrating a commitment to user satisfaction. Address easy fixes quickly and be transparent on how issues are being addressed. 

This prevents frustrations from festering and turning into something bigger than the original problem. 

Embrace a culture of continuous improvement that monitors not only the technology but the environment that it supports. Be responsive to changes like shifts in process steps and to those teams engaged in the process.

These all have an impact on the original design of the tool that will need to be adjusted to reflect the new environment.  

By incorporating these strategies, legal technology can become more approachable, user-friendly, and aligned with the human aspects of the legal profession.

Humanizing legal technology enhances its acceptance, adoption, and overall impact on legal professionals and clients.

Elizabeth Lugones is COO/ Senior Advisor of UpLevel Ops who has built and managed Legal Operations teams in various industries in both public and private companies over her 20+ year career. She excels in global project management and business reengineering, with particular expertise in process improvement, change management, cross-functional collaboration, and team building, but her true passion is helping others find their own strengths and talents and harness them for the value of all.

# The Hemp Advancement Act: A Good Or A Bad Omen For The Hemp Industry?
## The following summary addresses the most significant provisions of the Act and how they would impact hemp stakeholders if enacted.
By [Nathalie Bougenies](https://abovethelaw.com/author/nbougenies/)  
onMarch 3, 2022 at 1:02 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/the-hemp-advancement-act-a-good-or-a-bad-omen-for-the-hemp-industry/&text=The%20Hemp%20Advancement%20Act:%20A%20Good%20Or%20A%20Bad%20Omen%20For%20The%20Hemp%20Industry?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/the-hemp-advancement-act-a-good-or-a-bad-omen-for-the-hemp-industry/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/the-hemp-advancement-act-a-good-or-a-bad-omen-for-the-hemp-industry/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Earlier this month, Representative Chellie Pingree, D-Maine, filed a new federal piece of legislation that proposes to “improve” the Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 (the 2018 Farm Bill)’s hemp provisions by replacing “unworkable and overly complicated regulations” that have hindered the growth and success of the hemp industry.

Yet, this nine-page bill, the “Hemp Advancement Act of 2022” (the Act), includes some reforms that may not entirely benefit the hemp industry.

The following summary addresses the most significant provisions of the Act and how they would impact hemp stakeholders if enacted.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Adopt A New Definition Of “Hemp”
The Act proposes to amend the 2018 Farm Bill’s definition of “hemp” in four major ways.

1. By increasing the THC limit in “hemp” from 0.3% to 1% on a dry weight basis.

This issue has been at the forefront of the campaign by hemp advocates who condemn the arbitrary nature of the level of allowable THC content in the hemp plant and the unnecessary burden it causes on hemp producers.

This THC threshold dates back to 1976, when Canadian horticulturalists Ernest Small and Arthur Cronquist published an article entitled, “A Practical and Natural Taxonomy for Cannabis,” in which the authors explained:

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
“It will be noted that we arbitrarily adopt a concentration of 0.3% delta-9 THC (dry-weight basis) in young, vigorous leaves of relatively mature plants as a guide to discriminating two classes of plants.”

In other words, Small and Cronquist never intended for the 0.3% limit to have legal significance. And yet, many governments, including the U.S., have relied and continue to rely on it.

So, all that, to say that this increase in THC levels would be a welcomed change for the hemp industry.

2. By replacing the “delta-9 THC concentration” with “Total THC concentration”

Despite its intent to increase the THC limit found in hemp, the Act also proposes to effectively lower the allowed THC limit by defining hemp and hemp product (note this term is defined separately from “hemp” in the Act) in terms of “total tetrahydrocannabinols concentration.”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Simply put, a “total THC concentration” includes more THC compounds than the existing total delta-9 THC concentration.

Practically speaking, this means that a hemp product that contains some trace amount of delta-8 THC (this is inevitable in working with hemp extract) and 0.3% total delta-9 THC would meet the Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018 (the 2018 Farm Bill)’s THC limit, and thus, be deemed lawful. However, under the Act, the same product would be unlawful. The mere inclusion of a minuscule, detectable amount of naturally derived delta-8 THC would push the product over the edge of the 0.3% threshold. Therefore, in order to comply with the total THC concentration, the finished product would have to contain a lower delta-9 THC concentration to make room for other detectable THC compounds, which means manufacturers of these products would need to adopt more stringent manufacturing practices.

3. By including the term “hemp extract” in the definition of “hemp”
If enacted in its current form, the Act would treat hemp extract as hemp, provided the extract:

- is not packaged as a finished product and sold to end use consumers but instead is used in the making of a finished product
- has a total tetrahydrocannabinol concentration that exceeds 1% on a dry weight basis” (emphasis added)
- is stored, transported, and processed in accordance with procedures that would be established by the USDA
Of particular interest here is the concentration level that would be allowed in hemp extract: more than 1% on a dry weight basis. This provision likely aims to address the complex issue of in-process hemp extract, which, though not meant to be sold to end-use consumers, is a vital component of all finished hemp-derived products.

In order to convert hemp (dry) into hemp extract (“wet” or liquid), the hemp plant must be processed using a method that inevitably raises the delta-9 THC levels above 0.3%, even if fleetingly. Although the 2018 Farm Bill legalized hemp by removing the plants, its derivatives, extracts, and cannabinoids from the definition of “marihuana” under the Federal Controlled Substances Act (the CSA), it does not address the processing of hemp, nor does the USDA’s Final Rule, which solely regulates the cultivation of hemp.

In August 2020, the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) took advantage of this regulatory gap and released an Interim Final Rule, which improperly criminalizes in-process hemp extract. This attack on in-process hemp extract is hugely problematic in that this substance, though not intended for sale to end-use consumers, is lawful under the 2018 Farm Bill and, as previously mentioned, is a vital component of all finished hemp-derived products intended for human consumption. In publishing its Interim Final Rule, the DEA has unduly burdened hemp processors with potential threats of enforcement action. Therefore, Pingree’s Act would help bring much-needed peace of mind for these stakeholders.

4. By providing “hemp” cannot be sold to end-use consumers
Under the Act, hemp (including hemp extract) could only be sold to other licensees. Only finished hemp products, which must contain no more than 0.3 percent total THC concentration, could be sold to end-use consumers.

Amend The Definitions Of “Marihuana” And “Tetrahydrocannabinol” Under The CSA
Although the Act seems to propose a solution to the issue of high level of THC found in in-process hemp extract, the proposed bill contains other provisions that may in fact further complicate the legal status of this substance.

The amendments proposed in the Act would:

- remove hemp (including hemp extract) and hemp products from the definition of “marihuana”
- exclude in-process hemp extract and hemp products from the definition of THC, which already excludes hemp (and thus, hemp extract)
While these exclusions seem favorable at a glance, they are problematic for two reasons:

- By only excluding in-process hemp extract from the definition of THC, the Act fails to remove the possibility that in-process hemp extract be treated as “marihuana” (i.e., as a controlled substance).
- The Act fails to appreciate that THC listed as a Schedule I substance under the CSA only includes synthetic THC. For more information on this issue, I strongly recommend reading Shane Pennington’s excellent article published on On Drugs.
Remove DEA Laboratory Registration Under USDA Regulations
The 2018 Farm Bill tasked the USDA with overseeing the production of hemp and with establishing regulations, including criteria by which a lab may be accredited for purposes of testing hemp to ensure compliance with federal law.

Pursuant to the USDA Final Rule, labs testing hemp must be registered with the DEA. The rationale for this rule is that labs could potentially handle hemp that tests above the THC testing limit, which would constitute “marijuana,” a Schedule I drug under the CSA. Because it is unlawful to possess marijuana without a DEA registration, all labs, therefore, must be registered with the DEA in order to conduct hemp THC testing.

Unfortunately, the current DEA rules limit registration to labs located in jurisdictions in which the prescription, distribution, dispensing, research, and handling of marijuana is legal. This, in turn, means that a very limited number of labs are authorized to engage in this industry. This is problematic given the fact that there are currently too few labs compared to the amount of hemp being produced.

So getting rid of this requirement would hugely benefit the hemp industry.

Prohibit Interstate Commerce Of “Synthetic Cannabinoids”

Section 8 of the Act proposes to amend Section 10114(a) of the 2018 Farm Bill to read as follows:

Nothing in this title or an amendment made by this title prohibits the interstate commerce of hemp (as defined in section 297A of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 (as added by section 10113)) or hemp products, “or permits interstate commerce of products containing cannabinoids that are not naturally occurring in the plant Cannabis sativa L. or that are manufactured by means of chemical synthesis.” (Emphasis added).

While Rep. Pingree explained in a press release that the Act aims to “ensur[e] final hemp products sold to consumers aren’t intoxicating,” which presumably confirms products containing delta-8 THC could not be sold across state lines (Delta-8 THC is an intoxicating cannabinoid produced through a chemical reaction that combines hemp-derived CBD with a solvent, acid, and heat), the bill fails to address the meaning of “manufactured by means of chemical synthesis” as well as that of the term “synthetic cannabinoids,” which is used in the title of Section 8. Therefore, unless Congress defines these terms, we’ll be left with more uncertainty regarding the legality of these “minor cannabinoids.”

Repeal The Exclusion Of Formerly Ineligible Applicants

This bill also proposes to repeal the controversial drug-felon ban that bars most persons with a felony drug-related conviction from obtaining a hemp license. If enacted, the Act would help ensure that communities of color, which have been disproportionately impacted by drug policies, would gain equal access and opportunity to engage in this emerging market.

Despite some of its problematic provisions, the Act is backed by more than a dozen major hemp and cannabis groups, including the U.S. Hemp Roundtable, Americans for Safe Access, and Hemp Industries Association.

Pingree shared in a recent statement that she is hopeful this piece of legislation will enjoy the same level of bipartisan support as the hemp legalization provisions of the 2018 Farm Bill saw and expects her bill will drive conversations and inform policy as federal lawmakers begin drafting the 2023 Farm Bill.

Let’s simply hope that when discussions begin, Congress is made aware of the issues discussed in this piece so it avoids enacting a bill that would further exacerbate the challenging situation in which the hemp industry has found itself for the past three years.

Nathalie Bougenies chairs [Harris Bricken](https://harrisbricken.com/)‘s hemp CBD practice group and focuses her practice on health and wellness, in addition to corporate transactions and regulatory compliance. For the past three years, Nathalie has helped clients navigate the complex regulatory landscape of hemp products intended for human consumption and advises domestic and international clients on the sale, distribution, marketing, labeling, and importation of these products. Nathalie frequently speaks on these issues and has made national media appearances, including on NPR’s “Marketplace.” She also authors a weekly column for “Above the Law” that features content on cannabis policy and regulation and is a regular contributor to her firm’s “[Canna Law Blog](https://harrisbricken.com/cannalawblog/).” For three consecutive years, Nathalie has been named Rising Star by Super Lawyers.

# Reflecting On My First In-Person Deposition Since The Shutdown
## Much is missed by holding depositions through remote means.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onOctober 14, 2020 at 4:48 PMOctober 14, 2020 at 2:02 PM
44
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/reflecting-on-my-first-in-person-deposition-since-the-shutdown/&text=Reflecting%20On%20My%20First%20In-Person%20Deposition%20Since%20The%20Shutdown)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/reflecting-on-my-first-in-person-deposition-since-the-shutdown/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/reflecting-on-my-first-in-person-deposition-since-the-shutdown/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As many people within the legal profession understand from first-hand experience, lawyers and courts have been conducting operations remotely since the COVID-19 pandemic began. Judges and court attorneys are usually holding hearings and conferences through Zoom or other similar mediums these days in order to reduce the risk that attorneys and court staff will be exposed to the virus. In addition, many depositions have been held remotely so that parties do not need to be together in one room during the proceedings. However, I recently had my first in-person deposition since the pandemic began, and the experience has shown me that there is much that is lost by holding depositions through remote means.

Rapport Between Attorneys

Of course, the most important part of a deposition is to receive sworn testimony from a witness. However, there are a number of other reasons why in-person depositions can be important to a case. Perhaps one of the most important aspects of in-person depositions is that is gets all of the attorneys connected to a case in one room, which can be helpful in moving a case forward. At an in-person deposition, attorneys can casually talk about discovery disputes, settlement numbers, and numerous other issues while everyone is together for the purpose of taking a deposition. Moreover, attorneys can build rapport with one another at in-person depositions in ways not possible during virtual depositions. For instance, many attorneys eat lunch together during breaks in a deposition, and this can go a long way toward building connections with other attorneys on your case and even in your practice area. I have never heard of attorneys eating their lunches together through Zoom during virtual depositions, and this rapport-building is essentially lost during virtual depositions.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Efficiency

One of the biggest benefits that I missed about in-person depositions is that taking testimony live is far more efficient than using Zoom or other remote means. When parties use Zoom or other applications, there is always the risk that internet disruptions and other technical glitches will make it difficult to take testimony. At virtual depositions, it is also sometimes hard to hear people, and individuals are far more likely to talk over each other, which can be difficult on the deponent, the attorneys, and perhaps more importantly, the court reporter.

Moreover, many of the procedural parts of a deposition are nearly impossible when depositions are conducted through virtual means. For instance, it is much more difficult (or impossible) to show a witness an exhibit during a virtual deposition, have them read from a writing, and ask questions pertaining to documents and other tangible items. Any good deposition taker will tell you that using exhibits is an important part of directing a witness, and this component of depositions is really hard with virtual proceedings. Moreover, using translators is much easier in person than during virtual depositions. Translators can already add to the time and complexity of a deposition, and this is even more of a challenge at virtual depositions. All told, my recent experiences with in-person depositions and virtual proceedings have shown me that in-person questioning can save both time and effort.

Witness Reactions And Sidebars

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Anyone who has participated in a deposition conducted over the phone or even by Zoom (or a similar app) knows that it is hard to discern witness reactions during virtual depositions. Being able to observe the reactions of a witness is extremely important to determining if a witness is telling the truth, is uncomfortable about certain topics, and other insights. The reactions can help inform an attorney’s perspective, and it is extremely difficult to get this understanding from virtual depositions.

In addition, virtual depositions make it much easier for attorneys to coach their client during a deposition. Some jurisdictions restrict the applicability of the attorney-client privilege during depositions because courts understand that it is important for witnesses to provide truthful and unguided testimony during depositions. However, it is much easier for attorneys to talk with clients without other counsel knowing about it when they are in a room together and everyone else is participating in a proceeding remotely. While I do not want to impugn anyone, everyone knows that coaching and other “funny business” often occurs at depositions, and this is much easier during virtual depositions.

Of course, I am not saying that virtual depositions shouldn’t take place during the pandemic, and lawyers — just like everyone else — need to follow the advice of medical professionals. It seems like virtual depositions will be a much bigger part of the legal profession for a long time, since health guidelines require social distancing and depositions usually bring people together. However, my recent experiences with both in-person and virtual depositions have shown me that virtual depositions should not be an ubiquitous and permanent fixture of the legal profession.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothmanlawyer.com](mailto:jordan@rothmanlawyer.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# White & Case Delivers For Child Victims As Part Of $600 Million Flint Water Settlement
## Pro bono effort secures services for most vulnerable victims.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 20, 2020 at 1:40 PMAugust 20, 2020 at 5:19 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/white-case-delivers-for-child-victims-as-part-of-600-million-flint-water-settlement/&text=White%20&%20Case%20Delivers%20For%20Child%20Victims%20As%20Part%20Of%20$600%20Million%20Flint%20Water%20Settlement)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/white-case-delivers-for-child-victims-as-part-of-600-million-flint-water-settlement/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/white-case-delivers-for-child-victims-as-part-of-600-million-flint-water-settlement/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There are a lot of reasons for the United States to be ashamed of itself right now, but if the country ever wanted to add a little bit more, it can recall that a global superpower allowed children to drink poisoned water for months and — six years after the fact — hasn’t fully finished fixing it. The crisis in Flint passed from a lot of people’s minds as newer miseries pushed it to the media back burner.

At White & Case, the matter remained front and center. The firm worked pro bono with the legal team representing the children of Flint including the ACLU of Michigan and the Education Law Center and [reached a partial settlement in 2018](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-power-of-pro-bono-biglaw-firm-scores-major-victory-for-victims-of-flint-water-crisis/) with the Michigan Department of Education, Genesee Intermediate School District, and Flint Community Schools. That settlement established a screening process to identify children displaying symptoms of lead poisoning and a second prong providing sophisticated psychological testing those children. A significant victory but it wasn’t the end of the fight.

Today, the firm announced that the new $600 million settlement with Michigan, which must still be approved by the court, will include a wide range of services tailored to address the long-term impact of the crisis including special education programs and universal pre-K.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Lindsay Heck, who we talked to back in 2018, offered the following:

“This is a landmark settlement in our special education case,” said Lindsay M. Heck, lead attorney from global law firm White & Case LLP, which worked on the case pro bono. “Lead is a potent neurotoxin that causes irreversible brain damage. There is no medical intervention that can completely counter the effects of lead exposure—education offers the only antidote. This settlement establishes a model to identify children with disabilities, to create structural changes that will ensure that those disabilities are properly addressed, and to prevent school discipline from being used as a substitute for behavioral interventions. It is a model that will not only transform the educational system for Flint children, but that establishes a framework for underfunded school districts in urban communities with deteriorating infrastructures that serve predominantly Black and Brown children. These communities have endured decades of educational disinvestment and environmental racism. We are committed to making sure this settlement turns Flint into a national symbol of resilience and hope.”

There’s still a lot of work to be done developing, implementing, and monitoring the settlement over the coming years, but today is a day for celebration. It’s a massive accomplishment and one that demonstrates the importance of pro bono efforts generally and the value a Biglaw firm can bring to the fight specifically.

(UPDATE: Worth throwing in there that for the overarching settlement Cohen Milstein Sellers & Tolls is interim co-lead class counsel and the whole case saw involvement from firms from Susman Godfrey to Weitz & Luxenberg.)

# Special Bonuses With A Side Of 'Significantly Increasing' Annual Bonus
## That's some exciting news.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMarch 31, 2021 at 10:30 AMApril 2, 2021 at 9:03 AM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/winston-special-bonuses/&text=Special%20Bonuses%20With%20A%20Side%20Of%20‘Significantly%20Increasing’%20Annual%20Bonus)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/winston-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/winston-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s not particularly surprising that Winston & Strawn will join the market in offering special bonuses. This one is a JSESDPWM (June-September Equal Split DPW Match). But what is surprising is a line tucked away at the bottom of the memo promising some even more exciting news at year-end.

Winston matches the market rate for annual bonuses every year, but has historically kicked a bit more into the annual bonus pool for high billers. Back in 2019, this [amounted to around $5K for 2200 hours and $7.5K for 2400](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/winston-bonus-2019/). This special bonus memo concludes by announcing, “we are pleased to announce that we are significantly increasing our year-end high hours bonuses.” That’s a tantalizing promise to drop on associates finishing up their first quarter of billing!

But we’ll have to wait to see what Winston’s going to offer next. For now, we’ve got June and September bonuses to think about.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  


Bonuses are available to associates hitting a 1900-hour annualized target — folks missing out in June have the opportunity to catch up. Congrats to all and we’re looking forward to more news about these high-biller bonuses!

[Full memo on the next page…](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/winston-special-bonuses/2/)

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.
